author: Mac Cerullo mcerullo@eagletribune.com
title: A dish best served cold
text:
Amanda Sabga A dish best served cold 
AMANDA SABGA/Staff Photo North Andover’s Austin Ward kicks the ball up field during Thursday night’s 4-0 win over Andover at North Andover High School. Amanda Sabga A dish best served cold 
AMANDA SABGA/Staff Photo Andover's Dimitri Jean-Laurent dribbles with the ball away from North Andover's Ryan Bessette during Thursday night's game at North Andover High School. Amanda Sabga A dish best served cold 
AMANDA SABGA/Staff Photo North Andover’s Ryan Bessette protects the ball from Andover’s Jeff Hunt during their game on Thursday night at North Andover High School. Amanda Sabga A dish best served cold 
AMANDA SABGA/Staff Photo Andover's Jeff Hunt protects the ball from North Andover's Connor Willis during their game Thursday night at North Andover High School. Amanda Sabga A dish best served cold 
AMANDA SABGA/Staff Photo Andover's Steven Schuhwerk readies to kick the ball as North Andover's Rory Martyn moves in on defense during Thursday's game at North Andover High School. Amanda Sabga A dish best served cold 
AMANDA SABGA/Staff Photo North Andover’s Erick Duffy fights for the ball with Andover’s Steven Schuhwerk during their game on Thursday night at North Andover High School. Posted: Friday, October 16, 2015 1:00 am A dish best served cold By Mac Cerullo mcerullo@eagletribune.com Eagle-Tribune 
NORTH ANDOVER — When the two rivals faced off in the season-opener, Andover had the upper hand. 
On Thursday night — however — the shoe was on the other foot, as North Andover boys soccer dominated its neighboring foe for a convincing 4-0 win. 
The victory avenged the lone loss of the season for North Andover (11-1-1). The Knights are now riding a 12-game unbeaten streak dating back to their 3-0 loss to the Golden Warriors. 
“We were a much better team coming in, and the mindset was revenge, obviously,” said senior Brendan Parisotto, who had two goals on the day. “We needed to just come back and beat them.” 
Parisotto got the Knights off to a fast start, breaking free from his defender down the right side of the field before going straight to the net to make it 1-0 in the fourth minute. North Andover controlled the pace from there, but it remained a one-goal game going into halftime. 
Early in the second half, Andover got a couple of its best chances, after senior Steven Schuhwerk fired an impressive scissor kick towards the net after a corner. But Knights goalie Paul DeMaio was there for the stop. 
Shortly after, North Andover extended its lead when junior Stephen Stabile beat Andover’s goalie to a contested ball, and set up Ryan Bessette for a goal to make it 2-0. 
In the final 10 minutes, North Andover finished the job with two more goals in quick succession, the first coming off a header by Parisotto, and the next off a rocket by Cam Twomey from just outside the box. 
Andover was playing without two of its top defensive players, center midfielder Raini Huynh and outside midfielder Mouhammed Thiam. They were both hurt in Saturday’s game against Lowell. 
“We have to to put the ball in the net, play tighter on defense, don’t give them open shots in the back and then just score,” said Andover coach Jim Saalfrank. 
Andover will face Lawrence on the road at 11 a.m., and North Andover will look to continue its streak when it hosts Lowell next Tuesday at 4 p.m. Sign Up / Sign In With your existing account from... {* loginWidget *}
